ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This was my first film course, and I learned to critically analyze films.
I learned how to critically analyze film for craft and political/philosophical undertones.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The contextual understanding of Forman's films you will have by then end of the course is amazing, but the course rarely touches on visual or cinematic analysis. If you are seeking that, you will have to bring the discussion to the table yourself.
The course was interesting and the professor was very flexible with assignments. This allowed for the class to focus solely on discussing the films.

A strength of the class was the depth of analysis Professor von Kunes has a excellent grasp on the material and communicated the nuances integral to popular views of Formans cinematography clearly and effectively. A weakness was that it was difficult to offer in writing a grounded critique of the films before we discussed them in class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would only recommend this class to students who have an interest in Czech history or culture. While the course includes Milos Forman's famous films, the majority of the course is focused on his lesser-known films.
Yes, it is well taught and allows me to view film more critically. A valuable skill to have.
